name: Ana Kokkinos
description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

start.title: Head On
start.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
start.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

end.title: Spotlights: Jill Bilcock
end.brief_description: An Australian film editor, a member of the Australian Screen Editors guild, as well as the American Cinema Editors society, who has edited films such as Romeo + Juliet (1996), Moulin Rouge! (2001) and Road to Perdition (2002).

constellations_primary.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_primary.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Acclaimed Australian film editor, Jill Bilcock not only worked on Baz Luhrmann’s Strictly Ballroom (1992) and Romeo + Juliet (1996), PJ Hogan’s Muriel’s Wedding and Shekhar Kapur’s Elizabeth during the 1990s, she also edited Kokkinos’ Head On in 1998.

start.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
start.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

end.title: Only the Brave
end.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Fiona Eagger and Pickpocket Productions
end.brief_description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Ana Kokkinos started filmmaking because to tell stories that represent Australia’s cultural and sexual diversity. Her first film, the Sundance Audience Award-winning Only the Brave, explored those themes through the story of two young Greek Australian girls growing up in Melbourne’s western suburbs.

start.title: Only the Brave
start.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Fiona Eagger and Pickpocket Productions
start.brief_description: Alex (Elena Mandalis) and Vicki (Dora Kaskanis) are two young Greek Australian girls in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Only together - committing arson, hanging out - do they find moments of peace in their lives.

end.title: Head On
end.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
end.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Kokkinos’ second film and first feature was an adaptation of Christos Tsiolkas’ novel Loaded. Like her first film, it deals with a queer Greek Australian character, Ari, “rebelling against the conditions and constraints his culture has placed on him”.

start.title: Head On
start.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
start.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

end.title: The Slap
end.creator_credit: Helen Bowden, Michael McMahon, Penny Chapman, Tony Ayres and Matchbox Pictures
end.brief_description: The Slap is an Australian television drama series based on the multi-award-winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

links.description: Head On star Alex Dimitriades worked on another Christos Tsiolkas adaptation, the TV mini-series The Slap, which also surveys class in suburban Melbourne and the migrant experience. The Slap follows different characters and their perspectives in the fallout of one incident.

start.title: The Slap
start.creator_credit: Helen Bowden, Michael McMahon, Penny Chapman, Tony Ayres and Matchbox Pictures
start.brief_description: The Slap is an Australian television drama series based on the multi-award-winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

end.title: The Family Law
end.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

constellations_primary.name: The Family Law
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of Asian representation on screens around the world that delves into TV, cinema, documentaries and Disney princesses.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

links.description: The Slap showrunner Tony Ayres has worked across a number of Australian film and TV properties, including another Tsiolkas adaptation, Baracuda (2016). He was also executive producer of The Family Law, another show that explores the immigrant experience in Australia.

start.title: The Family Law
start.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

constellations_primary.name: The Family Law
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of Asian representation on screens around the world that delves into TV, cinema, documentaries and Disney princesses.

end.title: Acropolis Now
end.credit_line:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
end.brief_description: In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens.

constellations_primary.name: Culture, food and family
constellations_primary.description: Food as a link to culture and family.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: While The Family Law is the first Australian sitcom about a Chinese Australian family, it’s not the first Australian sitcom to tell non-white Australian stories. It follows in the footsteps of hit sitcom Acropolis Now, which like Kokkinos’ work, surveyed the Greek diaspora in Melbourne.

start.title: Acropolis Now
start.credit_line:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
start.brief_description: In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens.

end.title: Head On
end.creator_credit: Ana Kokkinos, Jill Bilcock, Jane Scott and Head On Productions
end.brief_description: Ana Kokkinos’s debut follows the angry, confused and nihilistic 19-year-old Greek Australian, Ari (Alex Dimitriades) through 24 hours fuelled by drugs, booze and anonymous sex as he grapples with his sexuality and clashes with his traditional Greek family.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Effie (Mary Coustas) stole the show in Acropolis Now with her comedic timing and trademark phrases “Hello! Good thanks” and “How embarrassment!”, the latter of which a Greek Australian character in Head On recites to Ari (Dimitriades), demonstrating the cultural impact of the show.

end.title: Seven Types of Ambiguity
end.creator_credit: Glendyn Ivin, Amanda Higgs and Matchbox Pictures
end.brief_description: A gripping psychological mystery told from the shifting perspective of six characters following a complicated chain of events triggered when a child is taken and relationships are thrown into crisis.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Like The Slap, Seven Types of Ambiguity is based on an Australian novel (by Elliot Perlman) and presents different perspectives of a crime while exploring middle-class Australia. Kokkinos directed the last two episodes of the mini-series, which also starred Dimitriades.

start.title: The Slap

end.title: The Oscars slap
end.brief_description: There are no winners in this Academy Award moment. Even those who took home Oscars had their achievement overshadowed by Will Smith’s startling assault on Chris Rock. When the internet should’ve been buzzing about Troy Kotsur winning the second Oscar awarded to a Deaf performer, or Jane Campion being only the third woman to win for Best Director, it was instead saturated by hot takes, memes and outrage – either for or against Rock’s joke or Smith’s reaction – in an ongoing feedback loop between broadcaster, viewer and meme-maker, which played out in real time during the ceremony.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: When Will Smith assaulted comedian Chris Rock at the 2022 Oscars, Australian meme-makers quickly drew comparisons to the TV adaptation of Tsiolkas’ novel. Ironically, Tsiolkas had just published a piece in The Saturday Paper about Oscar scandals.
